Having been taught to the catechumens on the Sunday before Easter, the Creed was rendered, that is to say, recited publicly‚ on Maundy Thursday.2 By this means its recita- tion was separated from the renunciation of the devil, which in the other rites precede it.

3. Baptism and Confirmation.

The observances for Easter Eve were much the same as those in use at Rome. The passages from Holy Scripture which constituted the lections were almost identical, and were, like the Roman 16550115, interspersed with hymns and prayers. At the appointed hour, all concerned proceeded to the baptistery,3 where the ceremony of initiation began by the blessing of the water.
